%c[ui_gray_2]A series of Soviet-made optical scopes in common use since 1964 when it was introduced as a standard issue telescopic sight for SVD sniper rifles. The scope has later been adapted to assault rifles such as the AK-74 or AN-94. It is recognized for its durability, versatility and well-designed reticule pattern, featuring a convenient range-finder. This particular scope has 4.0x Magnification rate. It is attached to weapons by means of a dovetail mount; the standard in Warsaw Pact countries.

%c[ui_gray_2]The USP-1 sight has an optical arrangement with a prism-erecting system. Sighting angles are set mechanically by turning the sight body relative to the weapon mounting bracket. Requires no batteries as it is tritium illuminated. The ranging scale at the edge of the sight's field of view has a range of up to 1200m.

%c[ui_gray_2]Standard-issue telescopic sight of the Red Army in World War II and years after. Designed to fit infantry and precision rifles such as the Mosin-Nagant or SVT-40. It features a fixed 3.5x zoom. Like all Soviet designs, it is durable and effective, remaining in production and use to this day.

%c[ui_gray_2]The ZF-4 is one of the first telescopic sights ever created. Designed and manufactured in Germany during World War II, it was intended to provide regular infantry with the ability to fight at long distances. It has been primarily used by German snipers and elite combat squads. The scope is still in use since weapons it has been designed for are commonly available.
